title: Bernoulli Variable and Algebraic Transformation
original_question: A student flips a fair coin where landing Heads (H=1) is a success and Tails (H=0) is a failure. The student defines a new variable $W = 3H^3 + H$. If the probability of landing Heads is exactly 0.5, what is the expected value $E[W]$? A fellow student suggests that because the coin is made of silver, the physical weight might affect $H^3$ differently than $H$. Note that the room temperature was 22°C. Calculate the final expected value.

segments.explanation: A Bernoulli variable takes only 0 or 1 as possible values.

segments.explanation: For a Bernoulli variable, $H^k = H$ because $1^k = 1$ and $0^k = 0$.

traps.title: The Power Misconception
traps.description: Students often fail to realize that for any Bernoulli variable $X$, $X^n = X$, leading to unnecessary complexity in calculating higher moments.

solution.content: Since it is a fair coin, $p = P(H=1) = 0.5$. The expected value $E[H] = p = 0.5$.

title: Sample Proportion and Standard Error
original_question: A population consists of 138 responses where the true proportion of 'interested' students is $p = 0.85$. A researcher takes a random sample of size $n = 36$. Another student claims that the standard deviation of the population, $\sqrt{p(1-p)}$, is the same as the standard error of the sample. Calculate the actual standard error of the sample proportion $\hat{p}$. Use the fact that $\sqrt{0.1275} \approx 0.357$.

segments.explanation: This is the true parameter p for the Bernoulli population.

segments.explanation: The population standard deviation $\sigma$ is $\sqrt{p(1-p)}$, while the standard error is $\sigma / \sqrt{n}$.

traps.description: Students often confuse the population standard deviation $\sigma$ with the standard error of the mean/proportion, forgetting to divide by $\sqrt{n}$.

title: Expectation and Profit Analysis
original_question: A die rolling game pays $120 for every six rolled ($S=1$) and $0 otherwise ($S=0$). The probability of a six is $1/6$. A player decides to roll the die 12 times. The entry fee for the entire 12-roll session is $200. A spectator claims that because 12 is a multiple of 6, the player is guaranteed to win exactly twice. What is the player's expected profit?

segments.text: A die rolling game pays $120 for every six rolled ($S=1$) and $0 otherwise ($S=0$).
segments.explanation: Each roll is a Bernoulli trial where $S=1$ represents a six.

segments.text: The probability of a six is $1/6$.
segments.explanation: The expected value for one roll is $E[S] = p = 1/6$.

segments.text: A player decides to roll the die 12 times.
segments.explanation: The expected number of sixes is $n \times p$.

segments.explanation: Expectation is an average over many sessions; in a single session, the actual number of sixes is random.

traps.title: The 'Guarantee' Fallacy
traps.description: Students may incorrectly think that because 12 is a multiple of 6, the outcome is fixed at exactly two sixes, confusing expected value with a guaranteed result.

solution.content: Let $S_i$ be the indicator for rolling a six on roll $i$. Then $E[S_i] = 1/6$ and $E\left[\sum_{i=1}^{12} S_i\right] = 12 \cdot (1/6) = 2$.

title: Complex Linear Transformation and Variance Analysis
original_question: Suppose you have two independent Bernoulli random variables, $X_1$ and $X_2$, both representing a die roll where success is a six ($p = 1/6$). A student defines a new random variable $V = 3(X_1 + X_2) + 5$. The student's assistant claims that because the variables are independent, the variance of the sum is simply the sum of the variances, but forgets how the constant '5' and the multiplier '3' affect the spread. Another observation from the lab notes indicates that the ambient noise level was 65 dB. Calculate the exact variance $Var(V)$ and identify if the constant '5' changes this result. Use the property that $Var(aX + b) = a^2 Var(X)$.

segments.text: Suppose you have two independent Bernoulli random variables, $X_1$ and $X_2$, both representing a die roll where success is a six ($p = 1/6$).
segments.highlight_text: two independent Bernoulli random variables, $X_1$ and $X_2$, both representing a die roll where success is a six ($p = 1/6$)
segments.explanation: Each variable has a mean $p$ and variance $p(1-p)$. Independence allows us to sum their variances directly.

segments.text: A student defines a new random variable $V = 3(X_1 + X_2) + 5$.
segments.explanation: Constants added to a random variable do not change the variance, but multipliers are squared.

segments.text: The student's assistant claims that because the variables are independent, the variance of the sum is simply the sum of the variances.
segments.highlight_text: variance of the sum is simply the sum of the variances
segments.explanation: This property holds true specifically for independent variables.

segments.text: Another observation from the lab notes indicates that the ambient noise level was 65 dB.
segments.explanation: Environmental noise levels do not impact the mathematical properties of random variable variance.

segments.text: Calculate the exact variance $Var(V)$ and identify if the constant '5' changes this result.
segments.explanation: $Var(aX + b) = a^2 Var(X)$. The constant $b$ (5) will be eliminated.

traps.title: The Constant Offset Trap
traps.description: Students often mistakenly add the constant (e.g., +5) to the variance or fail to square the multiplier (3) when calculating the spread of a transformed variable.

traps.title: Independence vs. Dependence
traps.description: If variables were not independent, a covariance term would be needed; students must verify independence before summing variances.

Calculate the variance of the sum (X1 + X2)
solution.content: Since $X_1$ and $X_2$ are independent, $Var(X_1 + X_2) = Var(X_1) + Var(X_2) = 5/36 + 5/36 = 10/36 = 5/18$.

solution.step_desc: Apply the transformation rule to find Var(V)
solution.content: $Var(V) = Var(3(X_1 + X_2) + 5) = 3^2 \times Var(X_1 + X_2) = 9 \times (5/18) = 5/2 = 2.5$. The constant '5' does not affect the variance.
